intro: Paraphyadanthe coriacea, commonly known as the roughleaf phlox, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Polemoniacaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and showy, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and has lance-shaped leaves with a rough, textured surface. Its flowers are usually pink or purple and bloom in late spring to early summer. Paraphyadanthe coriacea is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological benefits to local pollinators.
